skills.name: Carry out addition problems involving one negative integer
Carry out missing number addition problems involving negative integers
Find the absolute value of a number
Determine the additive inverse of a given number
Relate a negative number as an absolute distance from 0 on a contextual number line other than a thermometer

explanations.A: I think you might have done 7 + 7. Take a closer look at the question, the first 7 is negative. What is -7 + 7?
explanations.C: Close! I think you might have included -7 when you started counting on. We're at -7 and jumping up by 7. Our first jump will put us at -6, second jump at -5 and so on...
explanations.D: Not quite! I think you might have missed out zero when you were counting on. We must count zero in, it is an integer between -1 and 1.

explanations.A: Close! I think you might have included -9 when you started counting on. We're at -9 and jumping up by 9. Our first jump will put us at -8, second jump at -7 and so on...
explanations.B: I think you might have done 9 + 9. Take a closer look at the question, the first 9 is negative. What is -9 + 9?
explanations.D: Not quite! I think you might have missed out zero when you were counting on. We must count zero in, it is an integer between -1 and 1.

explanations.A: Not quite! I think you may have started counting on -3. The first jump is the first one we count so when starting at -3 the first jump takes us to -2. You could also think about if we are 3 below zero then what do we add to get back up to zero?
explanations.B: I think you may have got mixed up with multiplying here as anything multiplied by zero is zero. But the question is asking what do you add to -3 to get to zero?
explanations.C: Be careful. If you are at -3 and then you add a negative, you will get even more negative; further away from zero. Is this what you want to do if you're trying to get up to zero?

explanations.A: Not quite! I think you may have started counting on -5. The first jump is the first one we count so when starting at -5 the first jump takes us to -4. You could also think about if we are 5 below zero then what do we add to get back up to zero?
explanations.C: I think you may have got mixed up with multiplying here as anything multiplied by zero is zero. But the question is asking what do you add to -5 to get to zero?
explanations.D: Be careful. If you are at -5 and then you add a negative, you will get even more negative; further away from zero. Is this what you want to do if you're trying to get up to zero?

explanations.A: I think you may have added 6 to zero to get 6 and the two sixes together to get 12. Have a look at where the zero is. What number will be to the left of that so that when we add 6 to it, we get zero? And what about when you are at zero and you add 6. What do you get?
explanations.B: The left box must be -6 as when we add 6 that takes us to zero. When at zero and we add 6 that gets us 6. So the two numbers are -6 and 6.
explanations.C: Almost! You have the correct value of -6. When you added 6 to that that took you to zero. So now you are at zero and adding 6 to get to the other box. What do you get?
explanations.D: Not quite! I think you might have added 6 to zero to get both of those answers. Try your answer; would 6 + 6 get you to zero? The left box has had 6 added to it to get to zero so if we wanted to work backwards to find what was in that box, what would we have to do?

explanations.A: Almost! You have the correct value of -4. When you added 4 to that that took you to zero. So now you are at zero and adding 4 to get to the other box. What do you get?
explanations.B: Not quite! I think you might have added 4 to zero to get both of those answers. Try your answer; would 4 + 4 get you to zero? The left box has had 4 added to it to get to zero so if we wanted to work backwards to find what was in that box, what would we have to do?
explanations.C: I think you may have added 4 to zero to get 4 and the two fours together to get 8. Have a look at where the zero is. What number will be to the left of that so that when we add 4 to it, we get zero? And what about when you are at zero and you add 4. What do you get?
explanations.D: The left box must be -4 as when we add 4 that takes us to zero. When at zero and we add 4 that gets us 4. So the two numbers are -4 and 4.

explanations.A: Be careful. Remember absolute value is the distance away from zero. The direction doesn't matter. How far away from zero is -5?
explanations.B: I think you may have mixed up absolute value with squaring. Remember absolute value is the distance away from zero. How far away from zero is -5?
explanations.C: Absolute value is the distance away from zero. -5 is 5 units away from zero so the answer is 5.
explanations.D: Remember the absolute value is the distance away from zero. It can be in either direction but it cannot be either negative or positive as a distance can't be negative.

explanations.A: Absolute value is the distance away from zero. -6 is 6 units away from zero so the answer is 6.
explanations.B: Remember the absolute value is the distance away from zero. It can be in either direction but it cannot be either negative or positive as a distance can't be negative.
explanations.C: Be careful. Remember absolute value is the distance away from zero. The direction doesn't matter. How far away from zero is -6?
explanations.D: I think you may have mixed up absolute value with squaring. Remember absolute value is the distance away from zero. How far away from zero is -6?

explanations.A: Be careful. We want the distance from -3 to zero. Can a distance be negative?
explanations.B: You're close! I think you may have included the -3 as you were counting on. We start at -3 so the first jump takes us to -2, the second jump to -1 etc. How many jumps are needed to get to zero?
explanations.C: If you are at -3 then you would need to go up 3 to reach zero. -3 + 3 = 0. So the answer is 3.
explanations.D: Not quite! I think you may have started at zero as well as including that value when you were counting on. Read the question carefully, where should you be starting from?

explanations.A: You're close! I think you may have included the -7 as you were counting on. We start at -7 so the first jump takes us to -6, the second jump to -5 etc. How many jumps are needed to get to zero?
explanations.B: Not quite! I think you may have started at zero as well as including that value when you were counting on. Read the question carefully, where should you be starting from?
explanations.C: Be careful. We want the distance from -7 to zero. Can a distance be negative?
explanations.D: If you are at -7 then you would need to go up 7 to reach zero. -7 + 7 = 0. So the answer is 7.
